Analysis.name: Psychosocial interventions versus inactive control; outcome 4: Adverse events
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: It is indicated that a computer-generated randomisation list was generated by the study statistician and random block of four, six and eight were used to ensure balance in the two arms. Participants were then allocated to a group by the study coordinator after the initial data had been collected. The contact information of intervention group participants was sent to the counsellors who commenced the intervention within 12 hours.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: "We cannot exclude the possibility that there were weaknesses in intervention delivery such as variations in the number of telephone calls, which could have attenuated the differences between the intervention and the control group."
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Low loss to follow up suggesting there was good opportunity to observe adverse events.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: There was low risk as the approach to measuring adverse effects seemed appropriate (monitoring worsening of outcome results)
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: "We also initially planned blinded external statistical analysis. Due to a lack of resources, both the continuous monitoring of results and the analysis were done within the research team, without blinding."
Overall.bias.support: Low loss-to-follow-up suggesting there was good opportunity to observe adverse events and the team was clearly attuned to importance of monitoring for adverse events, however, there were some problems with blinding of results.

Analysis.name: Psychosocial interventions versus inactive control; outcome 4: Adverse events
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: “After diagnostic assessment and completion of baseline outcome measures, a research assistant randomised participants to either trial condition using a virtual coin toss programme.” “Randomisation did not yield equal allocation across the two groups. There were also some notable group differences in the distribution of other participant characteristics.”
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: We did not detect any bias related to the intervention that could have influenced adverse events.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Care was taken to consider and report reasons for people leaving the study and there was high level of contact with participants through the study giving opportunity to identify adverse events.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: We found no indication of measurement bias.
Overall.bias.support: It is conceivable that the imbalance at baseline on characteristics of participants could have interacted with outcomes including susceptibility to adverse events.

Analysis.name: Psychosocial interventions versus inactive control; outcome 4: Adverse events
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc:
"Participants were admitted to the study in cohorts of 10 and randomly assigned to treatment or control groups by the site manager. This assignment was based on
a list of random numbers, previously generated at an independent location using Microsoft Excel 2016’s random number function."
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: No indication of deviation from planned intervention.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: There was high completion of the intervention and responses rates in the post-treatment phase were high so opportunity for adverse event reporting existed. There was greater loss over time however it is expected adverse events would have occurred during or soon after the intervention.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: "No reportable adverse events occurred." However, there was not a clear description of how adverse events were monitored or recorded.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: Not entirely clear how they planned to measure and report adverse events.
Overall.bias.support: Whilst risk of bias is minimal given general reporting of this trial, it was difficult to assess in regards to this outcome due to lack of methodological information.

Analysis.name: Psychosocial interventions versus inactive control; outcome 4: Adverse events
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: "To mask treatment assignment, patients mailed back a postcard after intake to complete entry into the protocol. The postcard’s time and date were logged into a computer and entered into a previously generated list of numbers that randomly assigned participants to treatment and control groups. All numbers and group assignments were generated at the start of the protocol."
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: This study gave no concern for deviation from interventions affecting the outcome
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: 44/88 lost in the intervention group and 28/80 lost in the control arm. "Imagery rehearsal therapy produces imagery adverse effects; 4 patients reported increased negative imagery and eventually withdrew, and 12 of 66 who completed treatment did not complete follow-up for unknown reasons."
Overall.bias.support: Adverse outcomes may have been the reason for drop-out and drop-out was high.

Analysis.name: Psychosocial interventions versus inactive control; outcome 4: Adverse events
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: "Participants were randomized to the interactive program or psychoeducational website based on a computerized coin flip."
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Participants and intervention deliverers probably aware of assignment.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: There was a high rate of attrition so some information about adverse events may not have been gathered.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: There was a high rate of attrition so some information about adverse events may not have been gathered.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: There are several ways of expressing treatment drop out and the authors may have selected a perspective that made the result look more favourable.
Overall.bias.support: The study reports a favourable rate of treatment adherence when in fact only 15.8% of people in the treatment group went through the full program.

Analysis.name: Psychosocial interventions versus inactive control; outcome 4: Adverse events
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: There was a large proportion of individuals excluded post randomisation and prior to allocation which raised some concerns. Also some disrepancy with the trial record for example according to the trial record, 63 were enrolled. However, several strengths in this domain, including: "Preparation of the trial material and randomization was conducted by the independent data and safety monitoring board Karolinska Trial Alliance (KTA) via sequenced computer-generated simple randomization with 1:1 allocation. Participants received sequentially numbered trial materials with concealed allocation. Allocation envelopes were kept and handled by the trial staff. Due to initial misunderstandings, the prepared sealed envelopes were initially not always picked in strict numeric order. However, the study was monitored and periodically reviewed by the KTA and the misunderstanding was corrected." No differences were reported around baseline characteristics.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: There was no cause for concern in how the intervention was delivered.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: "No reportable adverse events occurred." The difficulty with adverse events is only knowing about what gets reported however the domain of assessment was given due consideration by the researchers. "Because this was the first randomized controlled treatment study conducted for the method, we followed the results in order to be able to detect adverse effects (i.e., elevated scores on self-rating at time point two)."
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: "Since this was the first study of MLI in this context, we were concerned about risk for adverse effects and therefore planned external continuous monitoring of the results."
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: No concerns arose about the selection of the reported result.
Overall.bias.support: The brevity of the intervention promoted completion and reduced risk of harm and dropout. Overall, data are a complete and reliable assessment of adverse events.

Analysis.name: Trauma-focused versus non trauma-focused interventions; outcome 2: Depressive symptoms, 6 months
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: There is a lack of information on the process of assignment.
